title: 114_s55
content: The "Offshore Fairness Act" is the short title of this legislation, which includes definitions for various terms. The Act defines terms such as "coast line," "existing interest," "expanded seaward boundary," and "expanded submerged land." The Act defines terms related to coastal boundaries, submerged land, interest owners, the Secretary of the Interior, and specific states. SEC. 3. SEAWARD BOUNDARIES OF CERTAIN STATES. The Submerged Lands Act is amended to establish seaward boundaries for certain coastal states, including Alabama, Florida, Georgia, Louisiana, Mississippi, North Carolina, South Carolina, and Virginia. The boundaries are set at a line 3 marine leagues from the coast as of the day before the enactment of the Offshore Fairness Act. The Submerged Lands Act is amended to set boundaries for coastal states, including Alabama, Florida, Georgia, Louisiana, Mississippi, North Carolina, South Carolina, and Virginia, at 3 marine leagues from the coast or more for certain states. SEC. 4. CONVEYANCE. The Secretary must notify each State of the right to request a conveyance of the United States' interest in expanded submerged land and convey it upon request. The Governor of the State will then have the authority to exercise the powers and duties of the Secretary under certain conditions. The State must agree to indemnify the United States from any liability related to the conveyance of expanded submerged land or administration of existing interests. The State must agree to indemnify the United States from any liability related to the conveyance of expanded submerged land or administration of existing interests. SEC. 5. EFFECT. The Act and its amendments do not affect existing rights to expanded submerged land within a State's seaward boundaries. This land is subject to Federal oil and gas mineral rights, considered part of the Federal outer Continental Shelf, and subject to leasing and revenue distribution laws. The Act and its amendments do not impact existing Federal oil and gas leases on the outer Continental Shelf. If a lease is divided due to conveyance, the portion on expanded submerged land will not take effect until after the lease expires. This section does not apply to future interests granted by the State. The State can tax within its seaward boundaries, including expanded submerged land granted after conveyance. However, existing Federal oil and gas leases are not affected by this Act. SEC. 6. JURISDICTION OF GULF COASTAL STATES WITH RESPECT TO GULF OF MEXICO RED SNAPPER. In this section, definitions for "exclusive economic zone" and "Gulf coastal state" are provided. Gulf coastal States bordering the Gulf of Mexico include Alabama, Florida, Louisiana, Mississippi, and Texas. The Gulf coastal States have exclusive fishery management authority for Gulf of Mexico red snapper with an approved fishery management plan ensuring sustainability. States have exclusive authority to manage Gulf of Mexico red snapper in coastal waters and the exclusive economic zone. The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration provides financial assistance for stock assessments and data collection.
